content.description:
Left hand on a knob on left arete, right on the big positive edge; left foot low on small edge, right heel hook... and go! Use the many slopers and rounded edges to head up over the high point of the boulder. So fun!

Beta:

https://youtu.be/WpPKasgc0t8
content.protection: 2 pads recommended: 1 on the ground, 1 draped over the boulder behind the problem. Initially I had simply leaned a pad against the side of the boulder, but popped off the problem and smashed my elbow into the top of it on one of the attempts; definitely recommend padding the top as well!
content.location: Just behind the first boulder you reach from the trail.

content.description:
Maybe the only slab with a mantle start?

Match sit start at the cube near the bottom of the arete, rock/mantle on to the slab, then follow the thin edges and monos (so many monos!) to the top. Avoid the left arete, but there is a nice edge out left that is fair game close to the top.

Beta:

https://youtu.be/TmTeyPxcJkc

Walk off back and down to the right (down left is a huge loose boulder).
content.location: Directly above/north of Tree Frog Style; scramble counter-clockwise up along the boulders to the start of the problem.

content.description: Sit start on nice side pulls, pull up and step in the small pod/slot foothold, then reach for the slopey rail to the left and follow it out of the pit.
content.protection: Pad (FA was with no pad; the sit start will probably be less awkward sit starting on a pad, though)
content.location: Scramble/chimney/squeeze into the pit (options!), is on south wall.

content.description:
Start at bottom of the narrow slab, rock on, and climb using the smooth face and left arete. A couple laps makes for a good footwork warm-up before trying Coyote Corner.

Beta:

https://youtu.be/n3eRzobjQSk

Variation: V-Easy (but only 1-star) - use everything to the right as well. Kills the flow/aesthetics of the slab, though. Option for beginner slab-ists testing their footwork.
content.location: Scramble down towards Coyote Corner and turn right.

content.description:
If the high concentration of jugs on the problem were spread out over 20 feet, would definitely be a 4 star problem!

One of the rare steep and easy jug hauls, so fun to run laps on! Start down in the cave with two good big edges (left is super positive, right less so but big) and a huge foothold. Bump up right to a jug, then high step and follow more jugs than you could ever want through to the peak of the boulder. Careful not to dab on the slab behind you...

Beta:

https://youtu.be/mpfPtQU11N8
content.location: 10 ft right of Coyote Corner, near east end of the dead log.

content.description:
Sit start right hand on obvious edge in middle of face, left hand on arete. Bump up left to a nice edge, right to arete, then do the fun press-out with the left foot on the face below the roof until you can raise your right foot onto the upper face (this fun move makes it worth climbing). Continue up for a mild top-out.

Beta:

https://youtu.be/H9ZAcHnQUmw
content.location: On the south side of the first boulder reached in the area.

content.description: Grab the two aretes and climb heading up the left side.
content.location: First boulder reached for the area, SE corner.

content.description:
The centerpiece of the area, named after the coyote mom and 3 pups that were playing around down the hill on the day this was cleaned and sent.

Follow the corner in the middle of the tall slab past a mini-roof and on to top out at the obvious wide ledge down left of the peak.

Beta:

https://youtu.be/6oSy3AnP7mA
content.protection:
One pad folded to fill in the gap, another open on top of it. It's a bit rocky at the base.

Disclaimer: The climbing is easy, but definitely not going to be a clean fall to the pads if you slip; could easily become R/X rated if your shoes catch on the slab and flip you for a head-first dive. Cheese-grating down the slab is probably the best outcome.
content.location: Once in the area, continue along the trail to the big walkable slab, then scramble around down to the start (can't miss it once on the big slab). South facing, lots of sun in the summer, but good friction even in the July heat.

content.description:
Mostly cool because of the hidden, yet amazing, undercling for the left hand start hold; right starts on the mini-arete. High step and rock on to the face and continue to the top. Small boulder under roof is off.

Beta:

https://youtu.be/hFkalcIuoag
content.location: First boulder along the trail, west side.
